text: :wave: Hello all! Wanted to share that we're hiring another Sr. Developer Advocate here at HubSpot. This role will be focused on you! (you read that right) -- we're looking to better support this growing global community through more support channels, tools, and technical resources. The role can be Boston-based or remote: <https://www.HubSpot.com/jobs/apply?gh_jid=1710263>
feel free to @ me, <@UFWNSVCHE> or <@U22PKFRU5> any time
Thanks for taking the time to read :slightly_smiling_face:
Thanks for posting this!
Hello! I am hoping to chat with an internal HubSpoter about deployment best practices and version control for an Enterprise site. I was directed here.
Specifically I was interested in combining github and a FTP jenkins job to create versioning and a Sandbox environment. Has anyone had success in this area, or can offer insights?
you build it and i will pay close attention :slightly_smiling_face:
Ive only veen manually syncing git via ftp to HS would love a better method
i started building a webpack setup, just didnt get too far
this can be done pretty easily with the static files (js/css/sass), but I haven't had any success doing it with the templates/modules themselves
i was working specifically with modules in mind
if you guys find a solution that’s working well let me know, would love to get something going like that with <#CCQSQ2C6L|crankshaft> to make dev and testing of that easier
i like how when you push your module code up to HubSpot, it refreshes the preview window automatically
on the plus side, the templates/modules do have a no-hassle autosaving/versioning system built into HubSpot's web IDE which is probably enough for most people
yea, it’s just not enough for auto-syncing with git repos
agreed
i am really hopeful HubSpot is going to roll a good local environment out this fall
beers on me
i've wasted a few hours trying to get the local hubl server running on a couple occasions and always end up giving up for one reason or another
I’ve gotten it working to a basic extent but didn’t fully get how it all worked
I’ve given up completely on the local server and I just use this: <https://github.com/Absanater/HubSpot-frontend-local>
yeah.  i wasted too much time on it
do you use this often <@U3A4KEWK1>?
wrong Ian.  but, yeah, I do
It’s incredible for local development.  Deploy is dead easy, and so is version control via your repo of choice
Close enough
ha
i should give it another go
yep, pretty much what I do but that looks nice
write scripts/styles locally and sync them to HubSpot
the markup is still stuck in the design manager, at least for me.
You can write markup locally as well with the above, but not for modules
For the record, _I_ haven't used that yet, but it does look cool
whoever get's that new Sr. Developer advocate job, this should be the first thing you advocate for :slightly_smiling_face:
lol
lol we’re starting a list for that person. Day 1 here’s your mountain of work
If anyone here has any questions at all about HubSpot-frontend-local, feel free to reach out.  There’s a couple bugs when you’re getting it up and running, but pretty easy stuff to sort out.
Also, if anyone does end up playing around with it, It would be awesome to collaborate and see if we can move the functionality forward.
open source all the things
I just want to write sass and use emmet.  if they’d put it in the design manager I’d shut up about all this local dev crap
haha

I can get by without scss - only killer feature it has over HubL  for me is the nesting. Emmet however… oh boy… that would make my year.

I’d by the HS devs who built it in a beer at emmets. :beers:

Whoever gets the Senior Dev Advocate role, here are your first assignments.
1. Emmet in the design manager.
2. Push for the local server to be made easier to use/and local syncing stuffs.
3.  Profit!!!!!!!! and :beer:  at emmets
Huzzah!
Wow I stepped into a 20 minute meeting and when I came back I was not expecting this response. So it seems the general consensus is 'No'?
basically - there’s no traditional method of staging a full HS CMS site. The closest thing is using the local server but many of us have had difficulty using it.

So we currently do something similiar, where we develop locally using a Hubl server, push to git, and run a jenkins job to dump files into the design manager--but the reason I've been looking for using the Dev space as a Sandbox is that the Hubl server doesn't seem to like a lot of modules that we are developing and keeps crashing.

Great discussion in this thread.

RE: developer tooling/local dev, I talk a bit about our plans here: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/HubSpot-Ideas/Allow-for-Design-Manager-Design-Tools-to-be-connect-to-a-GitHub/idi-p/269034>

We are actively thinking about and working on how developing on the HubSpot CMS could support any development workflow.

Supporting this platform agnostic workflow would allow for code living in GitHub, writing SASS, using VSCode/their plugins (Emmet), etc., and any other current or future web development trend.

Un-winding the HubSpot design system to support this is complicated, and we want to get it right (think true file representations of HubSpot objects and their settings). As Stefen mentioned, static assets like CSS and JS are more straight forward, but the HubSpot objects (templates, modules, etc.) and all of their fields are more difficult to truly represent in a file format.

We have made exciting progress on this front, and will certainly involve the developer community in it's evolution over time once it is ready to be tested to ensure it solves your development workflow needs.

Previewing is another concept we are looking to improve in the near future. Once the local workflow is more realistic, having confidence your local changes will impact live content as intended is a really important component of developer success, and needs to be 1:1 - previewing can not be just _close_ to the live result, it should be representative.
This is really great stuff to hear!
I know that if you have errors in your code, HubSpot won't let you upload it. Perhaps same applies here?
